questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with left-sided headache and facial pressure. CT scan shows complete opacification of the sinus as shown by the arrow. (Twisted PYQ)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Frontal sinus

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The image shows complete opacification of the frontal sinus with:
  • • Blocked frontal recess Mucosal thickening Air-fluid level Classic appearance of frontal sinusitis with outflow obstruction Superior location in relation to orbit
  • • Blocked frontal recess
  • • Mucosal thickening
  • • Air-fluid level
  • • Classic appearance of frontal sinusitis with outflow obstruction
  • • Superior location in relation to orbit
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Maxillary sinus:
  • • Option A. Maxillary sinus:
  • • Located inferior to the orbit and lateral to the nasal cavity, which doesn't match the location shown in the image.
  • • Option B. Ethmoid sinus:
  • • Option B. Ethmoid sinus:
  • • Located between the orbits in a honeycomb pattern, not matching the single large air space shown in the image.
  • • Option D. Sphenoid sinus:
  • • Option D. Sphenoid sinus:
  • • Located posterior to ethmoid air cells, not visible in this coronal plane at this level.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ To identify the frontal sinus on coronal CT imaging and recognize the radiological appearance of frontal sinusitis with outflow tract obstruction, which can lead to serious complications if left untreated due to its proximity to the brain.

questions.text: A surgeon wants to perform frozen section analysis during total thyroidectomy to rule out malignancy. Which staining technique would be most appropriate? [Twisted PYQ]
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) H&E

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • H&E (Hematoxylin and Eosin) staining is the gold standard for frozen section analysis during thyroid surgery. It provides excellent nuclear and cytoplasmic detail necessary for identifying malignant changes in thyroid tissue. Hematoxylin stains nuclear material blue/purple while eosin stains cytoplasmic components pink/red, allowing clear visualization of cellular architecture and nuclear features crucial for diagnosing thyroid malignancy.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Supravital staining (like Toluidine blue) : While useful for in-vivo examination during laryngoscopy, it's not suitable for frozen sections as it doesn't provide the detailed cellular architecture needed for definitive diagnosis of thyroid malignancy.
  • • Option A. Supravital staining (like Toluidine blue)
  • • Option C. Congo red : This special stain is specifically used to identify amyloid deposits. It has no role in routine frozen section analysis of thyroid tissue for malignancy.
  • • Option C. Congo red
  • • Option D. Silver nitrate : This is primarily used as a cauterizing agent and for highlighting reticular fibers. It's not suitable for routine frozen section analysis where nuclear and cytoplasmic details are crucial.
  • • Option D. Silver nitrate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ To understand that H&E staining remains the standard technique for frozen section analysis during thyroid surgery, providing necessary detail for identifying malignant changes, unlike supravital stains which are better suited for in-vivo examination.

questions.text: What are the air cells located at the anterior most part of the anterior ethmoidal sinus called?(AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Agger nasi

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Agger nasi is the anterior-most air cells of anterior ethmoid air cells. Bulla ethmoidalis is the largest air cells in ethmoidal air sinus Onodi cell/ Sphenoethmoidal air cell is the posterior most ethmoidal air cells Haller cells are ethmoid air cells that extend into the floor of the orbit and can affect the integrity and drainage of the maxillary sinus
  • ➤ Agger nasi is the anterior-most air cells of anterior ethmoid air cells.
  • ➤ Bulla ethmoidalis is the largest air cells in ethmoidal air sinus
  • ➤ Bulla ethmoidalis
  • ➤ Onodi cell/ Sphenoethmoidal air cell is the posterior most ethmoidal air cells
  • ➤ Onodi cell/ Sphenoethmoidal air cell
  • ➤ Haller cells are ethmoid air cells that extend into the floor of the orbit and can affect the integrity and drainage of the maxillary sinus
  • ➤ Ref - Dhingra 7 th edition, Page No. 152, 153
  • ➤ Ref - Dhingra 7 th edition, Page No. 152, 153

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents to the emergency department with sudden onset dysphagia. The chest x-ray shows a radiopaque object in the upper esophagus as shown in the image 1. The object has been present for approximately 6 hours, and the child now has developed stridor. What is the sign known as depicted in image 2? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Steeple sign

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ To recognize that button battery ingestion can lead to rapid complications including airway compromise, and the importance of identifying both the primary foreign body and its secondary complications on imaging.

questions.text: Following total thyroidectomy, a patient started having difficulty in breathing, and repeated attempts to extubate were unsuccessful. The most probable cause is: (NEET PG 2021)
questions.correct_answer: C. Bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve injury
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve injury

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve injury after thyroidectomy is a serious complication that can lead to life-threatening airway obstruction. Immediate recognition and management are crucial to ensure the safety and recovery of the patient.
  • ➤ Ref - Dhingra 7 th edition, Page No. 339
  • ➤ Ref - Dhingra 7 th edition, Page No. 339

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with progressive dyspnea and stridor 3 months after recovery from severe COVID-19 requiring prolonged ICU stay. Endoscopic evaluation reveals the finding shown in the image, along with significant circumferential scarring and calcification. The most appropriate classification system for this condition would be: (Twisted PYQ)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) McCaffrey

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ To understand that while Cotton-Meyer classification is widely used for simple subglottic stenosis, complex cases with extensive scarring and multi-level involvement may be better classified using the McCaffrey system, which considers additional factors beyond just the degree of stenosis.

questions.text: Identify the sinus marked in the given image: (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Maxillary sinus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ethmoid Sinus : Located between the nose and the eyes, within the ethmoid bone. It is a collection of small air cells. Frontal Sinus : Located above the eyes, in the frontal bone. These are typically well above the maxillary sinuses. Sphenoid Sinus : Located deeper and more centrally behind the nasal cavity, in the sphenoid bone. Maxillary Sinus: Located beneath the orbits, on either side of the nose.
  • ➤ Ethmoid Sinus : Located between the nose and the eyes, within the ethmoid bone. It is a collection of small air cells.
  • ➤ Ethmoid Sinus
  • ➤ Frontal Sinus : Located above the eyes, in the frontal bone. These are typically well above the maxillary sinuses.
  • ➤ Frontal Sinus
  • ➤ Sphenoid Sinus : Located deeper and more centrally behind the nasal cavity, in the sphenoid bone.
  • ➤ Sphenoid Sinus
  • ➤ Maxillary Sinus: Located beneath the orbits, on either side of the nose.
  • ➤ Maxillary Sinus:

questions.text: A 45-year-old male heavy smoker presents with progressive hoarseness and inability to project his voice while teaching. Laryngoscopy reveals a unilateral immobile, lateralized vocal cord in the paramedian position. Which muscle is most likely involved? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Posterior cricoarytenoid

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The posterior cricoarytenoid muscle is the only abductor of the vocal cords. When paralyzed, it results in:
  • • Inability to abduct the vocal cord Vocal cord remains in paramedian position Difficulty with voice projection Breathiness in voice due to incomplete glottic closure
  • • Inability to abduct the vocal cord
  • • Vocal cord remains in paramedian position
  • • Difficulty with voice projection
  • • Breathiness in voice due to incomplete glottic closure
  • • The presentation of a lateralized, immobile cord in the paramedian position strongly suggests posterior cricoarytenoid muscle paralysis, typically due to recurrent laryngeal nerve injury.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Thyroarytenoid: This muscle's paralysis would cause a bowed cord appearance but wouldn't result in a lateralized position. It affects voice quality by causing breathiness but through a different mechanism.
  • • Option B. Thyroarytenoid:
  • • Option C. Cricothyroid: While this muscle's paralysis affects pitch control, it doesn't cause cord lateralization. The cord would appear lax and bowed rather than fixed in a paramedian position.
  • • Option C. Cricothyroid:
  • • Option D. Lateral cricoarytenoid: This muscle's paralysis would affect adduction but wouldn't cause the cord to be fixed in a lateralized position. It would present with a more medial positioning defect.
  • • Option D. Lateral cricoarytenoid:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ To understand that posterior cricoarytenoid muscle paralysis results in a characteristic lateralized, paramedian position of the vocal cord, distinguishing it from other laryngeal muscle paralyses which present with different cord positions and mobility patterns.

questions.text: Which of these options is not a causal factor for head and neck malignancies? (NEET PG 2019)

Ans. D) Vitamin A deficiency

Occupational exposure: Exposure to wood or nickel dust or formaldehyde - a risk factor for cancers of the paranasal sinuses and nasal cavity Radiation exposure is a risk factor for salivary gland tumors, thyroid gland carcinoma
  • ➤ Alcohol use
  • ➤ Tobacco use (smoking or chewing)
  • ➤ Viruses HPV 16 - oropharyngeal cancer EBV – Nasopharyngeal cancer
  • ➤ HPV 16 - oropharyngeal cancer EBV – Nasopharyngeal cancer
  • ➤ HPV 16 - oropharyngeal cancer
  • ➤ EBV – Nasopharyngeal cancer
  • ➤ Paan (betel quid) – Oral cancers especially in gingivobuccal sulcus
  • ➤ Preserved or salted food consumption - nasopharyngeal carcinoma.
  • ➤ Occupational exposure: Exposure to wood or nickel dust or formaldehyde - a risk factor for cancers of the paranasal sinuses and nasal cavity Radiation exposure is a risk factor for salivary gland tumors, thyroid gland carcinoma
  • ➤ Exposure to wood or nickel dust or formaldehyde - a risk factor for cancers of the paranasal sinuses and nasal cavity Radiation exposure is a risk factor for salivary gland tumors, thyroid gland carcinoma
  • ➤ Exposure to wood or nickel dust or formaldehyde - a risk factor for cancers of the paranasal sinuses and nasal cavity
  • ➤ Radiation exposure is a risk factor for salivary gland tumors, thyroid gland carcinoma

questions.text: During the process of conducting a caloric test, what kind of nystagmus should one anticipate when using cold water irrigation?(AIIMS MAY 2018)

options.label: A
options.text: Horizontal nystagmus towards the same side

options.label: B
options.text: Vertical nystagmus towards the same side

options.label: C
options.text: Horizontal nystagmus towards the opposite side

options.label: D
options.text: Vertical nystagmus towards the opposite side

questions.correct_answer: C. Horizontal nystagmus towards the opposite side
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Horizontal nystagmus towards the opposite side

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The caloric test, particularly when using cold water, is designed to stimulate the horizontal semicircular canal, resulting in horizontal nystagmus towards the opposite side. This test is critical for evaluating unilateral weaknesses in the vestibular system and helps in diagnosing conditions affecting balance and spatial orientation.
  • ➤ Ref - Dhingra 7 th edition, page No. 45
  • ➤ Ref - Dhingra 7 th edition, page No. 45

questions.text: Identify the blue line shown in the below picture:( AIIMS May 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Ohngren's line

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ohngren's line is used to classify maxillary carcinomas into suprastructure and infrastructure based on their location relative to the line, which is critical for determining the prognosis and approach for surgical intervention.

questions.text: Organize the subsequent structures in the auditory pathway, beginning from the receptors and moving towards the cortex: ( INICET May 2023) Auditory Cortex Spiral ganglion Cochlear Nucleus Lateral leminiscus Inferior colliculus Olivary complex Medial geniculate body
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 2-3-6-4-5-7-1

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

  • ➤ AUDITORY PATHWAY
  • ➤ E – Eighth nerve
  • ➤ C – Cochlear nucleus
  • ➤ O – Olivary complex (superior)
  • ➤ L – Lateral lemniscus
  • ➤ I – Inferior colliculus
  • ➤ M – Medial geniculate body
  • ➤ A – Auditory cortex

questions.text: A 35-year-old female patient presents with complaints of nasal obstruction and post-nasal drip. There is a past history of FESS (Functional endoscopic sinus surgery) for failed conservative management 5 years ago. Uncinectomy and maxillary ostium dilation was done during the previous FESS. A DNE done now shows patent ostia and mucosal edema of the maxillary sinus lining. What is the next best step in management? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Steroid irrigation and antihistamines

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For a patient with nasal obstruction and post-nasal drip post-FESS with no current acute infection or structural issues, conservative management using steroid irrigation and antihistamines is recommended to manage inflammation and alleviate symptoms.
  • ➤ Ref - Dhingra 7 th edition, Page No. 213, 214
  • ➤ Ref - Dhingra 7 th edition, Page No. 213, 214

questions.text: A post-COVID patient, who is a known diabetic, develops unilateral facial pain and loosening of teeth. Which investigation would you do to confirm the diagnosis on this patient? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Biopsy with histopathologic examination

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Early diagnosis and aggressive treatment are critical for patients suspected of rhino-orbital-cerebral mucormycosis, especially in those with risk factors like diabetes and a recent COVID-19 infection. A biopsy with histopathologic examination is essential for confirming the diagnosis. This condition requires a multidisciplinary approach involving antifungal therapy, surgical debridement, and meticulous management of underlying conditions like diabetes to prevent serious complications and improve outcomes.

questions.text: A 15-year-old male patient presents with profuse spontaneous nasal bleeding in ENT emergency. On physical examination: Patient seems pale having Hb: 9 gm/dl. On CECT: a mass is seen which pushes septum to the contralateral side & anterior bowing of maxillary antrum is seen. All of the given statements are true regarding this mass except? (FMGE JULY 2023)

options.label: A
options.text: Most commonly seen in adolescent male

questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Best treated by radiation

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • The patient’s symptoms and examination findings, including profuse spontaneous nasal bleeding, pallor, and a mass pushing the septum to the contralateral side with anterior bowing of the maxillary antrum (Colman-Miller sign), are indicative of juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (JNA). This condition is most commonly seen in adolescent males, can spread to the orbit and intracranially, but it is not best treated by radiation. The primary treatment for JNA is surgical resection, not radiation therapy.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Most commonly seen in adolescent male: This is correct. JNA predominantly affects adolescent males.
  • • Option A. Most commonly seen in adolescent male:
  • • Option B. Can spread to orbit: This is correct. JNA can extend into the orbit due to its aggressive nature.
  • • Option B. Can spread to orbit:
  • • Option D. Can spread intracranially: This is correct. JNA can invade the cranial cavity, leading to significant complications.
  • • Option D. Can spread intracranially:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (JNA) is a condition that is most commonly seen in adolescent males and primarily treated with surgical resection, not radiation.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents with chronic productive cough and recurrent respiratory infections. His chest X-ray shows bronchiectasis with normal cardiac position. Semen analysis reveals immotile spermatozoa. [Twisted PYQ]

options.label: B
options.text: Primary Ciliary Dyskinesia without situs inversus

questions.correct_answer: B. Primary Ciliary Dyskinesia without situs inversus
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Primary Ciliary Dyskinesia without situs inversus

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • The image shows bronchiectasis with normal cardiac position (unlike the original which showed dextrocardia). Combined with the history of chronic respiratory symptoms and male infertility due to immotile sperm, this presentation is diagnostic of Primary Ciliary Dyskinesia (PCD) without situs inversus. While PCD with situs inversus is known as Kartagener syndrome, about 50% of PCD cases occur without situs inversus.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Kartagener syndrome : This requires the presence of situs inversus along with bronchiectasis and sinusitis. The normal cardiac position in this case rules out Kartagener syndrome.
  • • Option A. Kartagener syndrome
  • • Option C. Young syndrome : While it presents with bronchiectasis and azoospermia, the pathogenesis differs from PCD. In Young syndrome, sperm is produced but obstructed, unlike the immotile sperm in PCD.
  • • Option C. Young syndrome
  • • Option D. Cystic fibrosis : Though it can present with bronchiectasis and male infertility, the mechanism is different. CF causes obstructive azoospermia due to congenital bilateral absence of vas deferens, not immotile sperm.
  • • Option D. Cystic fibrosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ To understand that Primary Ciliary Dyskinesia can occur with or without situs inversus, and when it occurs with situs inversus, it's specifically called Kartagener syndrome. The presence of bronchiectasis with immotile sperm but normal cardiac position differentiates PCD without situs inversus from Kartagener syndrome.

questions.text: Which of the following is an indication of high tracheostomy? (NEET PG 2018)

options.label: D
options.text: Suspicion of Laryngeal carcinoma planned for surgery later

questions.correct_answer: D. Suspicion of Laryngeal carcinoma planned for surgery later
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Suspicion of Laryngeal carcinoma planned for surgery later

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ High tracheostomy is specifically indicated for suspicion of laryngeal carcinoma planned for surgery, as this condition requires eventual removal of the larynx, allowing for the creation of a fresh tracheostome in a new, clean area.
  • ➤ Ref - Dhingra 7 th edition, Page No. 359
  • ➤ Ref - Dhingra 7 th edition, Page No. 359

questions.text: Following a surgical procedure on the lateral aspect of the skull base, the patient experiences postoperative aspiration. However, there is no alteration in the patient's voice. What could be the explanation for this?( AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Superior laryngeal nerve injury

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Injury to the superior laryngeal nerve, particularly its internal branch, is a plausible explanation for the patient's aspiration post-surgery, especially when there is no accompanying change in voice quality. This suggests that the sensory function above the vocal cords is compromised, increasing the risk of aspiration without necessarily affecting voice modulation handled by the external laryngeal nerve.

questions.text: The image of a drug is given below. It is used in which of the following conditions? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Subglottic stenosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Mitomycin-C is particularly effective in preventing the recurrence of subglottic stenosis after surgery due to its antifibrotic properties, making it a critical adjunct in surgical procedures involving the airway.
  • ➤ Ref - Scott Brown 8 th edition, volume 3, Page No. 1088
  • ➤ Ref - Scott Brown 8 th edition, volume 3, Page No. 1088

questions.text: A young woman, aged 25, presented with hearing impairment that emerged shortly after her initial pregnancy. Provided below is her audiometry findings. What could be the potential diagnosis for this case? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Otosclerosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of these characteristics is not linked to superior semicircular canal dehiscence syndrome?(AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Sensorineural hearing loss

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In SSCDS, conductive hearing loss is typical due to the additional pathway for sound and pressure transmission created by the dehiscence, not sensorineural hearing loss, which involves damage to the hair cells in the cochlea or the auditory nerve. Understanding these distinct characteristics helps in accurately diagnosing and managing the condition.
  • ➤ Ref - Scott Brown 8 th edition, volume 2, Page no. 843-847
  • ➤ Ref - Scott Brown 8 th edition, volume 2, Page no. 843-847

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presented with vertigo, tinnitus and fluctuating hearing loss. The audiogram is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis based on the given image? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Meniere’s disease

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The most likely diagnosis for a patient presenting with vertigo, tinnitus, fluctuating hearing loss, and an audiogram showing low to mid frequency sensorineural hearing loss is Meniere’s disease.

questions.text: Which among the following statements is true about keratosis obturans? (NEET PG 2019)

options.label: A
options.text: Failure of migration of desquamated epithelium along posterior metal wall

options.label: B
options.text: Widening of meatus and facial nerve palsy might be seen

questions.explanation:
Ans. D) All of the above

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Keratosis obturans is characterized by the accumulation of epithelial cells in the ear canal, leading to potential structural damage and associated symptoms. Its management requires careful removal of the buildup and monitoring for complications such as facial nerve palsy. Awareness of its association with bronchiectasis and sinusitis is crucial for comprehensive patient care.

questions.text: Which structures pass between superior and middle constrictor? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) IX nerve (Glossopharyngeal Nerve)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The IX nerve (Glossopharyngeal nerve) and the stylopharyngeus muscle pass between the superior and middle constrictor muscles of the pharynx.

questions.text: Which of the following are the objective tests for the hearing? ( INICET May 2021) BERA (Brainstem evoked response audiometry) OAE (Otoacoustic emission) PTA (Pure tone audiometry) Tympanometry
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 1, 2 and 4

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Objective hearing tests like BERA, OAE, and Tympanometry provide essential diagnostic information without the need for patient interaction, distinguishing them from subjective tests like Pure Tone Audiometry which rely on patient responses.

questions.text: Mucormycosis can be caused by following except? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Broad spectrum antibiotics

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Risk factors for mucormycosis are:
  • ➤ Risk factors for mucormycosis are:
  • ➤ Uncontrolled diabetes Prolonged or high-dose corticosteroid therapy Post - organ transplantation Neutropenia Intravenous drug use Prolonged hospitalization Immunodeficiency
  • ➤ Uncontrolled diabetes
  • ➤ Prolonged or high-dose corticosteroid therapy
  • ➤ Post - organ transplantation
  • ➤ Neutropenia
  • ➤ Intravenous drug use
  • ➤ Prolonged hospitalization
  • ➤ Immunodeficiency

questions.text: The image given shows a patient who has undergone total laryngectomy due to laryngeal cancer. Identify the method of voice generation for this patient, as depicted in the provided image.(AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Tracheoesophageal prosthesis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tracheoesophageal prosthesis is a common and effective method for voice restoration following total laryngectomy. It relies on a surgically implanted device that directs air into the esophagus where vibrations are created for speech, significantly enhancing the quality of life for patients who have lost their natural voice box.

questions.text: A pregnant woman presented with hearing loss. On PTA, the amount of hearing loss was 56dB: (FMGE JULY 2024)

options.label: A
options.text: Ossicular fixation with intact tympanic membrane

options.label: B
options.text: Ossicular fixation without intact tympanic membrane

questions.correct_answer: A. Ossicular fixation with intact tympanic membrane
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Ossicular fixation with intact tympanic membrane

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Otosclerosis often presents as progressive conductive hearing loss with an intact tympanic membrane, and the hearing loss can worsen during pregnancy. The classic finding is ossicular fixation, particularly of the stapes bone.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man has arrived with a gradual swelling on the left side of his face persisting for two weeks. He had a prior incident of trauma involving wood, which occurred two months ago. A contrast-enhanced CT scan of the nasal passages and paranasal sinuses reveals a mass within the subcutaneous tissue of the left cheek. Examination of a tissue sample obtained via biopsy indicates the presence of a foreign body granuloma, with positive staining observed using PAS and GMS methods. What is the likely diagnosis? ( INICET May 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Phycomycosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Phycomycosis should be considered in patients with a history of trauma, swelling, and positive fungal stains (PAS and GMS), particularly if they have underlying conditions like diabetes or immunosuppression.

questions.text: From which of the following structures does the saccule develop? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Pars inferior

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The developmental origins of the inner ear structures, such as the saccule from the pars inferior, is crucial for comprehending various auditory and vestibular functions, as well as pathologies associated with these areas.
  • ➤ Ref - Dhingra 7 th edition, Page No. 13
  • ➤ Ref - Dhingra 7 th edition, Page No. 13

questions.text: Which staging is related to JNA? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Radkowski staging system is specifically used for staging Juvenile Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma (JNA), assessing its extent and guiding treatment options.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of tubercular otitis media? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Earache

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Earache is notably absent in tubercular otitis media, differentiating it from other types of middle ear infections where pain is a common symptom. Recognizing the painless nature of this condition is crucial for prompt and accurate diagnosis and management.

questions.text: Identify the structure marked in the image? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Fossa of Rosenmuller

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Fossa of Rosenmuller's familiarity is essential in nasopharyngeal examinations, especially in the context of identifying potential sites for nasopharyngeal carcinoma or other pathologies. Its recognition during endoscopy guides thorough inspection and appropriate clinical interventions.

questions.text: In a prolonged intubation patient, the following is seen. Staging for this is given by: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Cotton Meyer

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Subglottic stenosis resulting from prolonged intubation is staged using the Cotton Meyer classification, which grades the severity based on the percentage of airway narrowing
  • ➤ Grade 1: 0-50% stenosis Grade 2: 51-70% stenosis Grade 3: 71-99% stenosis Grade 4: 100% stenosis (complete obstruction)
  • ➤ Grade 1: 0-50% stenosis
  • ➤ Grade 1:
  • ➤ Grade 2: 51-70% stenosis
  • ➤ Grade 2:
  • ➤ Grade 3: 71-99% stenosis
  • ➤ Grade 3:
  • ➤ Grade 4: 100% stenosis (complete obstruction)
  • ➤ Grade 4:

questions.text: A patient presents with the complaint of inability to close the eye, drooling of saliva, and deviation of the angle of the mouth. Which of the following nerves is most likely to be affected? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Facial nerve

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Prompt recognition and treatment of facial nerve paralysis are crucial for improving outcomes and preventing permanent damage. Treatment primarily involves medication to reduce inflammation and supportive care, especially for eye protection.
  • ➤ Ref - Dhingra 7 th edition, Page No. 103, 104
  • ➤ Ref - Dhingra 7 th edition, Page No. 103, 104

questions.text: In what situations does Gelle's test yield a negative result?(AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Otosclerosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Gelle’s test is instrumental in diagnosing conditions involving ossicular chain mobility. A negative Gelle's test, indicating ossicular fixation, is particularly indicative of otosclerosis, which is crucial for determining appropriate management strategies, including potential surgical interventions like stapedectomy for improving hearing.
  • ➤ Ref - Dhingra 7 th edition, Page No. 24, 25
  • ➤ Ref - Dhingra 7 th edition, Page No. 24, 25

questions.text: A patient presents to the OPD with bilateral hearing loss with worsened right ear hearing loss. On examination, the doctor diagnose Otosclerosis and recommends stapedectomy as a final resort to the problem. What would be the findings of tuning fork tests based on which the doctor has recommended stapedectomy? (INICET Nov 2023)

options.label: A
options.text: Rinne’s test positive , Weber’s test lateralized to left ear

options.label: B
options.text: Rinne’s test positive , Weber’s test lateralized to right ear

options.label: C
options.text: Rinne’s test negative , Weber’s test lateralized to left ear

options.label: D
options.text: Rinne’s test negative , Weber’s test lateralized to right ear

questions.correct_answer: D. Rinne’s test negative , Weber’s test lateralized to right ear
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Rinne’s test negative, Weber’s test lateralized to right ear

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The combination of a negative Rinne test and Weber test lateralizing to the ear with more hearing loss is indicative of conductive hearing loss in that ear. In otosclerosis, the ossification of the stapes leads to mechanical dysfunction, preventing effective sound transmission, hence a stapedectomy might be recommended to mechanically bypass the ossified stapes and improve hearing.

questions.text: The radiograph presented below has been taken to enhance the evaluation of the frontal sinus. What is the widely used term for this particular perspective?( INICET Nov 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Caldwell view

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: A female singer with hoarseness of voice, unable to sing higher frequency notes. Bowed and depressed unilateral vocal cord is seen. Which muscle is involved? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Cricothyroid

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The cricothyroid muscle is essential for producing high-frequency notes by tensing the vocal cords. Paralysis of the cricothyroid muscle leads to the inability to produce these higher notes due to a lack of tension in the vocal cords.

questions.text: An audiogram of a 30-year-old female patient is given below. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Otosclerosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The audiometric profile of Otosclerosis: this typically presents as a conductive hearing loss with an air-bone gap on an audiogram, most often diagnosed in young adults, particularly females.

questions.text: Identify the part of the cochlear implant marked? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Grounding electrode

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The grounding electrode or reference electrode in a cochlear implant is implanted in the temporalis area and is crucial for accurate signal transmission by providing a reference point for electrical signals.

questions.text: What is the surgery done to widen the cartilaginous part of the external auditory canal called? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Meatoplasty

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Meatoplasty is an important surgical option for managing conditions that require improved access to the ear canal and middle ear, particularly in managing chronic ear diseases or anatomical changes that impact ear function.
  • ➤ Ref - Dhingra 7 th edition, Page No. 32, 457, 463
  • ➤ Ref - Dhingra 7 th edition, Page No. 32, 457, 463

questions.text: Which of the following nerves is responsible for referred otalgia from tonsillitis? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Glossopharyngeal nerve

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Referred otalgia from tonsillitis is most commonly mediated through the glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX), highlighting the importance of the nerve's role in sensory transmission from the tonsils and tonsillar fossa to the ear.
  • ➤ Ref - Source Dhingra 7th edition pg 143, 144
  • ➤ Ref - Source Dhingra 7th edition pg 143, 144

questions.text: Which of the following features will not be manifested in an infection of the post-styloid compartment of the parapharyngeal space?( AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Trismus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Presentation in a post-styloid abscess:
  • ➤ Presentation in a post-styloid abscess:
  • ➤ Bulge behind posterior tonsillar pillar.
  • ➤ Since post styloid compartment contains CN IX, X, XI, XII, their palsies may be seen. Sympathetic chain involvement in this compartment will cause Horner's syndrome. Swelling of the parotid region No trismus or minimal trismus General Symptoms - Fever, odynophagia, sore throat, torticollis (due to spasm of prevertebral muscles) and signs of toxemia
  • ➤ Since post styloid compartment contains CN IX, X, XI, XII, their palsies may be seen.
  • ➤ Sympathetic chain involvement in this compartment will cause Horner's syndrome.
  • ➤ Swelling of the parotid region
  • ➤ No trismus or minimal trismus
  • ➤ General Symptoms - Fever, odynophagia, sore throat, torticollis (due to spasm of prevertebral muscles) and signs of toxemia
  • ➤ Diagnosis
  • ➤ Diagnosis
  • ➤ Contrast-enhanced CT scan neck – for extent of a lesion. Magnetic resonance arteriography is useful if thrombosis of the internal jugular vein or aneurysm of the internal carotid artery is suspected.
  • ➤ Contrast-enhanced CT scan neck – for extent of a lesion.
  • ➤ Magnetic resonance arteriography is useful if thrombosis of the internal jugular vein or aneurysm of the internal carotid artery is suspected.
  • ➤ Treatment
  • ➤ Treatment
  • ➤ IV antibiotics with aerobic and anaerobic cover Incision and drainage of abscess
  • ➤ IV antibiotics with aerobic and anaerobic cover
  • ➤ Incision and drainage of abscess

questions.text: A 13-year-old girl presents to the ENT OPD with a complaint of nasal obstruction for the past two months. Her mother also reports foul-smelling discharge from the nose. On nasal endoscopy, the obstruction caused by crust formation is noted. She denies any bad smell. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Atrophic Rhinitis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Atrophic rhinitis is characterized by chronic nasal obstruction, crust formation, and foul-smelling discharge. The patient’s denial of the bad smell indicates anosmia, which is common in atrophic rhinitis. This condition typically leads to the formation of crusts within the nasal cavity, causing obstruction and a foul odor noticed by others but not by the patient due to their reduced sense of smell.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Rhinitis Medicamentosa: This condition results from prolonged use of nasal decongestant drops (e.g., oxymetazoline or xylometazoline), leading to rebound nasal congestion, not crust formation or foul-smelling discharge.
  • • Option A. Rhinitis Medicamentosa:
  • • Option B. Rhinosporidiosis: Caused by Rhinosporidium seeberi, it presents with polypoid masses in the nasal cavity but not with crust formation and foul-smelling discharge.
  • • Option B. Rhinosporidiosis:
  • • Option D. Rhinoscleroma : Caused by Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis, it presents with a hard, woody nose and specific histopathological findings, not just crust formation and foul-smelling discharge.
  • • Option D. Rhinoscleroma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Atrophic rhinitis presents with chronic nasal obstruction, crust formation, and foul-smelling discharge, often accompanied by anosmia.

questions.text: Identify the abnormal finding in this cochlear implant radiograph that requires immediate revision: (Twisted PYQ)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Extracochlear electrode migration

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The abnormal finding shown is electrode migration outside the cochlear turns, which requires immediate surgical revision. When electrodes migrate out of the cochlea (extracochlear migration), it results in:
  • • Loss of stimulation to specific frequency regions Potential damage to surrounding structures Ineffective auditory processing Risk of facial nerve stimulation
  • • Loss of stimulation to specific frequency regions
  • • Potential damage to surrounding structures
  • • Ineffective auditory processing
  • • Risk of facial nerve stimulation
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B: Receiver-stimulator displacement While this can occur, it typically presents differently on imaging with obvious displacement of the internal receiver package from its bed.
  • • Option B: Receiver-stimulator displacement
  • • Option C: Short electrode array insertion Partial insertion would be visible as a shortened array within the cochlea but would be identified during initial surgery.
  • • Option C: Short electrode array insertion
  • • Option D: Ground electrode disconnection Ground electrode issues typically present with device malfunction rather than visible radiographic changes.
  • • Option D: Ground electrode disconnection

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ To recognize complications of cochlear implantation that require revision surgery, particularly electrode migration which can cause both functional failure and potential complications if left untreated.

questions.text: A 14-year-old male presents with recurrent epistaxis and a nasopharyngeal mass showing significant intracranial and cavernous sinus extension on initial CECT. Which investigation would be most appropriate for surgical planning? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) MRI with contrast

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • In cases of JNA with intracranial and cavernous sinus extension, MRI with contrast becomes the investigation of choice for surgical planning because:
  • • Superior soft tissue resolution for evaluating intracranial extent Better visualization of cavernous sinus involvement Ability to differentiate tumor from retained secretions Excellent delineation of dural involvement No radiation exposure in young patients Better assessment of post-operative changes if needed
  • • Superior soft tissue resolution for evaluating intracranial extent
  • • Better visualization of cavernous sinus involvement
  • • Ability to differentiate tumor from retained secretions
  • • Excellent delineation of dural involvement
  • • No radiation exposure in young patients
  • • Better assessment of post-operative changes if needed
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. CECT: While excellent for initial diagnosis and bony erosion assessment, it provides limited soft tissue resolution for intracranial extension compared to MRI.
  • • Option A. CECT:
  • • Option C. Digital subtraction angiography: Though useful for embolization planning, it doesn't provide adequate anatomical detail of intracranial extension needed for surgical planning.
  • • Option C. Digital subtraction angiography:
  • • Option D. CT angiography: Provides good vascular mapping but inferior to MRI for soft tissue delineation and intracranial spread assessment.
  • • Option D. CT angiography:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ To understand that while CECT is the initial investigation of choice for JNA, MRI becomes the preferred modality when there is intracranial extension, as it better delineates the relationship with critical neurovascular structures needed for surgical planning.

questions.text: A patient presents to the OPD with complaints of vertigo, sensorineural hearing loss and tinnitus which lasts minutes to hours with accompanied nausea and vomiting. On investigation, there is endolymphatic hypertension present. What is the diagnosis? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Meniere’s disease

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Meniere’s disease is a chronic condition that requires management of symptoms through lifestyle changes, medications to control vertigo, and sometimes more invasive treatments to manage fluid pressure in the inner ear.

questions.text: Identify the condition shown in the image. ( INICET May 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Adenoid facies

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Adenoid facies can be recognized by characteristic features such as elongated face, open mouth posture due to nasal obstruction, hitched up upper lip revealing crowded upper teeth, and a pinched-in nose. It's associated with chronic adenoid hypertrophy, impacting the facial structure and respiratory function.

questions.text: In a patient with unilateral vestibular schwannoma causing complete vestibular loss, when performing caloric testing with cold water irrigation in the affected ear, what will be the expected direction of nystagmus? [Twisted PYQ]

options.label: B
options.text: Fast phase away from affected side

questions.explanation:
Ans. C) No nystagmus

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • In complete vestibular loss due to vestibular schwannoma, caloric stimulation of the affected ear will produce no response because the vestibular apparatus is completely non-functional. Cold water normally induces an inhibitory response causing nystagmus with fast phase to the opposite side, but when there's complete vestibular loss, there will be no nystagmus at all as the end organ cannot respond to thermal stimulation.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Fast phase towards affected side : Incorrect because cold water normally produces nystagmus with fast phase away from the stimulated ear, and in complete vestibular loss, no nystagmus would occur at all.
  • • Option A. Fast phase towards affected side
  • • Option B. Fast phase away from affected side : This would be the normal response in a healthy ear to cold caloric stimulation, but with complete vestibular loss, the ear cannot respond to caloric stimulation.
  • • Option B. Fast phase away from affected side
  • • Option D. Vertical nystagmus : Caloric testing produces horizontal nystagmus in normal conditions. Vertical nystagmus is not a possible response to caloric testing.
  • • Option D. Vertical nystagmus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ To understand that in complete vestibular loss, caloric testing on the affected side produces no nystagmus due to complete loss of vestibular function, unlike in partial vestibular dysfunction where diminished responses might still be seen.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female patient presents in the ENT OPD with complaints of pain and discharge from the ear. Examination reveals the following findings. What is the best line of treatment? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Clotrimazole ear drops

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The patient presents with pain and discharge from the ear, and the examination shows black-headed filamentous growths on the otoendoscopic picture. This indicates a fungal infection, specifically otomycosis caused by Aspergillus niger. The best treatment for otomycosis is an antifungal agent.
  • • otomycosis caused by Aspergillus niger.
  • • Clotrimazole an antifungal and is typically used to treat otomycosis.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Clotrimoxazole ear drops : Not an antifungal drug.
  • • Option A. Clotrimoxazole ear drops
  • • Option B. Ciprofloxacin ear drops: Ciprofloxacin is an antibiotic and is used to treat bacterial infections. It does not have antifungal properties.
  • • Option B. Ciprofloxacin ear drops:
  • • Option D. Wax softening ear drops: Wax softening ear drops contain ingredients like paradichlorobenzene, chlorbutol, and turpentine oil, which are used to soften ear wax. This treatment is irrelevant in the context of a fungal infection.
  • • Option D. Wax softening ear drops:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Otomycosis, a fungal infection of the ear, caused by Aspergillus niger, should be treated with antifungal agents like Clotrimazole ear drops.

questions.text: Which of these structures are retained during radical neck dissection? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Sublingual gland

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Ref - Dhingra 7 th edition Page No. 442; Stell and Maran 5 th edition Page No. 710

questions.text: On the promontory, behind the tympanic membrane, there is a red mass. CT is given. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The presence of a red mass on the promontory behind the tympanic membrane, with an absent caroticojugular spine on CT (felp sign), indicates a diagnosis of glomus jugulare.

questions.text: A patient present with oral cavity findings as seen in the image below. He is a smoker. What would you choose as your next step in the management of this patient? ( AIIMS Nov 2018)

options.label: B
options.text: Cessation of smoking and do biopsy

questions.correct_answer: B. Cessation of smoking and do biopsy
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Cessation of smoking and do biopsy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For leukoplakia, particularly in smokers, the primary management strategy includes cessation of smoking and histological examination through biopsy. This is crucial not only to assess the current state of the lesion but also to guide further therapeutic decisions which may include surgical excision, laser ablation, or cryotherapy depending on the biopsy results. Regular monitoring and photographic documentation of the lesion are also important for long-term follow-up.
  • ➤ Ref - Dhingra 7 th edition, Page No. 253
  • ➤ Ref - Dhingra 7 th edition, Page No. 253

questions.text: In a patient with severe subglottic stenosis as shown in the chest X-ray (note the narrowing below the vocal cords), which emergency airway procedure would be most challenging to perform? [Twisted PYQ]
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Cricothyroidotomy

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • In subglottic stenosis, a cricothyroidotomy becomes particularly challenging because the stenosis lies immediately below the cricothyroid membrane. The narrowed, scarred airway in this region makes it difficult to:
  • • Identify the cricothyroid membrane accurately Create an adequate opening through the stenosed segment Insert and secure the airway tube through the narrowed passage Achieve adequate ventilation due to the underlying stenosis
  • • Identify the cricothyroid membrane accurately
  • • Create an adequate opening through the stenosed segment
  • • Insert and secure the airway tube through the narrowed passage
  • • Achieve adequate ventilation due to the underlying stenosis
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Tracheostomy : While technically challenging, a tracheostomy can be performed below the level of stenosis where the tracheal anatomy is more normal, making it relatively more feasible than cricothyroidotomy.
  • • Option A. Tracheostomy
  • • Option C. Endotracheal intubation : Though difficult through the stenosed segment, can still be attempted with a smaller tube size guided by direct visualization.
  • • Option C. Endotracheal intubation
  • • Option D. Laryngeal airway : As it sits above the level of stenosis in the supraglottic region, it remains a viable temporary option for ventilation.
  • • Option D. Laryngeal airway

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ To understand that in subglottic stenosis, cricothyroidotomy becomes particularly challenging due to the anatomical distortion and narrowing at the precise location where the procedure needs to be performed, while other airway options might still be viable depending on the stenosis extent and location.

questions.text: A child has bilateral SNHL. Which of the following is not preferred in the child? (INICET MAY 2024)

options.label: C
options.text: Making him sit in front row in class

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Adenoidectomy with grommet insertion

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Adenoidectomy with grommet insertion is not preferred for treating bilateral sensorineural hearing loss as it addresses conditions causing conductive hearing loss, not sensorineural hearing loss.

questions.text: Which of these options is not a division originating from the external carotid artery within Kiesselbach's plexus? ( INICET Nov 2020)

options.label: D
options.text: Septal branch of superior labial artery

questions.correct_answer: A. Anterior and posterior ethmoidal arteries
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Anterior and posterior ethmoidal arteries

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ ARTERIAL SUPPLY OF THE NOSE:
  • ➤ ARTERIAL SUPPLY OF THE NOSE:
  • ➤ Internal carotid system -
  • ➤ Internal carotid system -
  • ➤ Branches of ophthalmic artery Anterior ethmoidal artery Posterior ethmoidal artery
  • ➤ Branches of ophthalmic artery
  • ➤ Anterior ethmoidal artery
  • ➤ Posterior ethmoidal artery
  • ➤ External Carotid System –
  • ➤ External Carotid System –
  • ➤ Sphenopalatine artery (branch of maxillary artery) gives nasopalatine and posterior medial nasal branches. Septal branch of greater palatine artery (branch of maxillary artery). Septal branch of superior labial artery (branch of facial artery).
  • ➤ Sphenopalatine artery (branch of maxillary artery) gives nasopalatine and posterior medial nasal branches.
  • ➤ Septal branch of greater palatine artery (branch of maxillary artery).
  • ➤ Septal branch of superior labial artery (branch of facial artery).
  • ➤ KIESSELBACH'S PLEXUS -
  • ➤ KIESSELBACH'S PLEXUS -
  • ➤ Four arteries anastomose at the anterior inferior part of nasal septum to form a vascular plexus called Kiesselbach's plexus.
  • ➤ Anterior ethmoidal Septal branch of superior labial Septal branch of sphenopalatine Septal branch of greater palatine
  • ➤ Anterior ethmoidal
  • ➤ Septal branch of superior labial
  • ➤ Septal branch of sphenopalatine
  • ➤ Septal branch of greater palatine
  • ➤ Ref - Dhingra 7 th edition, Page No. 198
  • ➤ Ref - Dhingra 7 th edition, Page No. 198

questions.text: Identify the marked structure in the given CT image. (INICET NOVEMBER 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Pneumatised superior turbinate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pneumatisation of the superior turbinate, indicates the presence of air spaces within the turbinates, which can have implications for nasal physiology and potential sinus pathologies.

questions.text: A gentleman presents to the OPD with a saddle nose deformity. He gives a past history of cough, on/off fever, and hemoptysis. On examination, septal perforation is present with pale granuloma. His chest x-ray showed multiple cavitary lesions, and the biopsy showed granuloma, multinucleated giant cells, and caseous necrosis. What would be the probable cause? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Tuberculosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tuberculosis should be considered in patients presenting with respiratory symptoms, systemic signs, and nasal deformities when accompanied by histological evidence of caseating granulomas. This constellation of findings is distinct in suggesting TB over other granulomatous diseases.
  • ➤ Granulomatous Disease of the Nose:
  • ➤ Granulomatous Disease of the Nose:

questions.text: Identify the air cell marked with red arrow in the CT scan of the nose and paranasal sinus: (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Bulla Ethmoidalis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Bulla Ethmoidalis is the largest and most constant air cell in the anterior ethmoid sinus.
